passages.text: Removal of FY26 ROE/CTargets, adding update, more one-off costs, whole of- loan safe potential flagged

BOQ provided a multi- faceted release to the market which: 1) flagged the removal of FY26 targets for \(8\%\) ROE and \(56\%\) cost/income ratio; 2) provided a trading update with no detail (\$375m to \$385m cash NPAT for FY25, vs consensus \$374m); 3) flagged the potential for a whole- of- loan sale for part of the equipment finance portfolio (no details provided, or certainty on a transaction proceeding); 4) flagged further below- the- line charges for 2H25; 5) flagged a partnership with Capgemini to lower cost to serve. Unfortunately, the trading update provides no insight into how much of the better profit performance relates to lower credit costs vs operational performance. A capital- efficient transaction had previously been discussed by the company, but there is no detail and such a transaction is unusual for a bank that is not growing quickly and does not have a strong distribution capability.

- FY25 guidance: BOQ expects to report cash earnings after tax in the range of \$375m to \$385m, up \(9\%\) to \(12\%\) on FY24. The mid-point of this guidance is \(-2\%\) ahead of Bloomberg consensus of \$374m and JPMc \$371m. BOQ also anticipates FY25 cash ROE uplift of between 50bps and 70bps on FY24 levels \((5.7\%)\) , still a very long way from the previously expected \(8\%\) for FY26. The trading update is very high level so we cannot pinpoint what drove this slightly better outcome, however we suspect it was driven by a more benign impairment expense outcome consistent with the BEN result earlier this week. JPM View: We currently forecast 4bps BDD/GLA for FY25 due to a pick up hoh from 1bp in 1H25 to an estimated 8bps in 2H25. We estimate that if the BDD/GLA was \(\sim 5\) bps in 2H25 (and we didn't change our other assumptions), this would put profit slightly above the midpoint of the guidance range.

- FY25 notable items: BOQ expects branch strategy costs of \$43m post tax, which includes \$16m incurred in 1H25. This is in line with the guidance previously issued of \$115m to \$125m pre tax. BOQ will also see restructuring costs of \$25m post-tax driven by ongoing operating model simplification. From FY26, all restructuring costs driven by simplification and transformation of the business will be included in ordinary operating expenses. Finally, BOQ will see a \$14m post-tax increase to the provision relating to works required under the 'Enforceable Undertaking with Austrac. This follows an updated assessment of remedial activities to complete the program. JPM view: The two new provisions are large in the context of BOQ and we estimate the two new provisions would take \(\sim 10\) bps off BOQ's CET1 ratio. This would further pressure BOQ's capital position, and may actually necessitate the capital efficient transaction flagged by management.

- Strategy update light on details: BOQ is exploring a whole-of-loan sale process of up to \$3.8bn of its equipment finance portfolio, aimed at enhancing capital flexibility, improving ROE and supporting customer growth. The sale is targeted for 1H26 but subject to agreeing terms, with no certainty it will proceed. JPM View: Management had already alluded to the potential for such
BOQ.AX,BOQ AU Price (27 Aug 25):A\$7.88 Price Target (Jun- 26):A\$6.10
See page 4 for analyst certification and important disclosures, including non- US analyst disclosures.

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
a transaction. However, the lack of detail makes the impact difficult to assess. We note that whole- of- loan sales are more typical for non- banks which are growing quickly.

- Walkback from FY26 targets: BOQ is no longer providing specific return on equity and cost-to-income targets to the market. BOQ had been targeting an FY26 ROE of 8% (FY26 JPMc 6.4%) and CTI of 56% (FY26 JPMc 62.5%). The market had long viewed these targets as unrealistic given the competitive dynamics in retail banking and BOQ's structural position in the market. JPM View: BOQ references "accelerating industry headwinds" for removing the target, which is hard to reconcile with recent results in the sector this reporting season.
Bank of Queensland (Underweight; Price Target: A\(6.10)

BOQ faced significant earnings pressure in FY24, but NIM trends flattened out in 1H25. BOQ has a bold cost- out plan (productivity program, OMB conversion) and transformation program, which should support good NPAT growth in FY25. However, beyond this, earnings growth flattens out given headwinds such as: 1) negative mortgage growth as BOQ pulls back from Broker; 2) normalisation of credit costs from very low levels. Stepping back, we see a very real risk that the disruption will have a meaningful impact on the franchise and revenue generation. Management's FY26 ROE and cost/income ratio targets still look very unrealistic to us, relying on an improvement in mortgage market competition that we do not expect to occur. In addition, cost programs/OMB conversions increase risks/uncertainties, especially with quite a tight capital position.

Our PT is at the midpoint of our absolute and relative valuations. Absolute valuation of \(\) 6.10\(reflects the aggregate of the present value of the dividend stream paid to shareholders through to FY27E and the present value of a multiple of FY27E tangible book value (using a long - run P/NTA multiple of 0.8x which reflects our est. sustainable ROTE of 8.25%). COE assumptions: 3.5% risk - free rate, 5.5% market risk premium, beta of 1.2 (execution risk on transformation, productivity, and OMB conversion programs). Our relative valuation of\) \ \(6.52\) is calculated based on a 42.5% discount to the ASX 200 Industrials 12mth fwd PER, multiplied by our 12mth fwd EPS forecast for BOQ.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the

price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid-cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
